statement.tex: \text{A die is thrown three times. Events A}\\ \text{and B are defined as follows}\\ \text{A: 5 on the first and 6 on the second throw.}\\ \text{B: 3 or 4 on the third throw.}\\ \text{Find the probability of B, given that}\\ \text{A has already occurred.}
\\ \textbf{Right or wrong? } \\ \text{We are required to find the following.}

reason.tex: \text{A has happened but B has not.}\\ \text{Therefore, we are looking for }P(B\vert A).\\ \text{Moreover, as per Bayes' Theorem }\\ \quad P(B\vert A) = \dfrac{P(A\cap B)}{P(A)}

\text{A die has no memory. So, what it does}\\ \text{in the third roll is independent of what it}\\ \text{did in the first two.}\\ \text{And hence, }P(A\cap B) = P(A)\cdot P(B).\\ \text{Notice that we did not even need to know}\\ \text{the value of }P(A).
